prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Tuning 1/18
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal represents spectral setup 1 of 18 in the unbiased spectral survey of IRAS16293-2422.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to cover the 329.15 to 362.90 GHz range in Band 7. Each science goal will observe 4 basebands of 468.75 MHz in sequence to cover a bandwidth of 1875 MHz at 0.25 km/s spectral resolution (employing a factor 2 spectral averaging to limit the data rate). To cover the proposed frequency range we will therefore require 18 separate tunings. We aim for a sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam / (km/s). The deepest systematic survey so-far by Caux et al. using the JCMT to survey this frequency window reached a sensitivity of about 125 mJy/beam / (km/s). With the proposed observations we will thus be more than a factor 20 more sensitive - and furthermore produce high quality images at 0.5 arcsecond resolution separating the emission from the different regions in the IRAS16293 environment not resolveable by single-dish observations. This sensitivity level will be comparable to what was achieved in the band 6 SV data - and reach the confusion limit at selected frequencies.
The analysis will consist of (i) identification of the lines (by frequency and similar spatial distribution); (ii) simulating the observed emission of a molecule in LTE including optical depth of the lines, with the excitation temperature and number of molecules as free parameters; if required by the data, the fit can contain more than one temperature component; (iii) determining families of molecules that correlate spatially and calculating their abundance ratios for comparison with models; (iv) determining the spatial variation of excitation temperature and abundances by carrying out item (ii) in different apertures and at different radii. We stress that most of our science involves relative abundance ratios, in particular with respect to CH3OH, which can be determined with much higher accuracy than absolute abundance ratios. With the proposed sensitivity, we can reach relative abundances with respect to methanol of 0.01-0.1% and absolute abundances down to 1e(-11)-1e(-10) with respect to H2, depending on species. For molecules for which collisional rate coefficients are available, we can also carry out full non-LTE calculations for a given physical structure of the source, and this will be done for simple molecules like HCO+, HCN and their isotopologues to determine accurate isotope ratios.

We adopt a spectral resoution of 0.25 km/s in each baseband. This is sufficient to resolve the narrow lines toward the B component of the binary as well as separate individul lines - while at the same time providing a broad enough simultaneous bandwidth for each science goal to make the project feasible. We will not utilize the spectral scan mode because tests with the ALMA-OT show that the difference in execution times are minimal for our requested sensitivity - and also the spectral scan mode was not applied to the already obtained ACA data (not possible).

The data rate is justified due to the desire to cover as broad a spectral window per science goal at the spectral resolution indicated above. Limiting the data rate (only marginally above the limit) would require decreasing the covered bandwidth in the individual science goal at increase the number of observed settings.
We aim for an angular resolution of 0.5" comparable to the extent of the complex organic molecules emitting toward each of the two protobinary components - as witnessed by previous observations.

With the proposed observations we will thus be more than a factor 20 more sensitive - and furthermore produce high quality images at 0.5 arcsecond resolution separating the emission from the different regions in the IRAS16293 environment not resolveable by single-dish observations. This sensitivity level will be comparable to what was achieved in the band 6 SV data - and reach the confusion limit at selected frequencies.
The analysis will consist of (i) identification of the lines (by frequency and similar spatial distribution); (ii) simulating the observed emission of a molecule in LTE including optical depth of the lines, with the excitation temperature and number of molecules as free parameters; if required by the data, the fit can contain more than one temperature component; (iii) determining families of molecules that correlate spatially and calculating their abundance ratios for comparison with models; (iv) determining the spatial variation of excitation temperature and abundances by carrying out item (ii) in different apertures and at different radii. We stress that most of our science involves relative abundance ratios, in particular with respect to CH3OH, which can be determined with much higher accuracy than absolute abundance ratios. With the proposed sensitivity, we can reach relative abundances with respect to methanol of 0.01-0.1% and absolute abundances down to 1e(-11)-1e(-10) with respect to H2, depending on species. For molecules for which collisional rate coefficients are available, we can also carry out full non-LTE calculations for a given physical structure of the source, and this will be done for simple molecules like HCO+, HCN and their isotopologues to determine accurate isotope ratios.

We adopt a spectral resoution of 0.25 km/s in each baseband. This is sufficient to resolve the narrow lines toward the B component of the binary as well as separate individul lines - while at the same time providing a broad enough simultaneous bandwidth for each science goal to make the project feasible. We will not utilize the spectral scan mode because tests with the ALMA-OT show that the difference in execution times are minimal for our requested sensitivity - and also the spectral scan mode was not applied to the already obtained ACA data (not possible).

The data rate is justified due to the desire to cover as broad a spectral window per science goal at the spectral resolution indicated above. Limiting the data rate (only marginally above the limit) would require decreasing the covered bandwidth in the individual science goal at increase the number of observed settings.
We aim for an angular resolution of 0.5" comparable to the extent of the complex organic molecules emitting toward each of the two protobinary components - as witnessed by previous observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal represents spectral setup 12 of 18 in the unbiased spectral survey of IRAS16293-2422.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to cover the 329.15 to 362.90 GHz range in Band 7. Each science goal will observe 4 basebands of 468.75 MHz in sequence to cover a bandwidth of 1875 MHz at 0.25 km/s spectral resolution (employing a factor 2 spectral averaging to limit the data rate). prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Understanding how, when and where complex organic and potentially prebiotic molecules are formed is a fundamental goal of astrochemistry and an integral part of origins of life studies. Already now ALMA is showing its capabilities for studies of the chemistry of solar-type stars with its high sensitivity for faint lines, high spectral resolution which limits line confusion, and high angular resolution making it possible to study young stars on solar-system scales. We here propose to undertake an unbiased survey of the protostellar binary IRAS 16293-2422 in the important spectral window from 329 to 363 GHz. This is a resubmission of a B ranked Cycle 2 program for which a significant amount of data have already been obtained and reduced.
The aim is to reveal the origin of complex organic molecules in a young protostellar system and investigate the link between this stage and the early Solar System. These data will however also have a large legacy value beyond the astrochemical focus of our group and we will therefore waive the proprietary period for the obtained data - and furthermore make the fully imaged datacubes available to the community with the first sets of papers.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Resubmission of partly completed proposal 2013.1.00278.S, "Formation of complex organics in solar-type protostars", Jes Jorgensen

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Niels Bohr Institute, Copenhagen, University of
Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of
Department of Chemistry, University of Virginia
Institute of Physics I, Cologne, University of
Harvard College Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
